articles.headline: Europe’s Drug Regulator Says AstraZeneca Vaccine Is Safe
articles.snippet: The European Medicines Agency will add a label to the shot, warning doctors to watch for possible rare, abnormal bleeding in the brain. But as the pandemic worsens in Europe, officials are desperate to fully resume its use.
articles.abstract: The European Medicines Agency will add a label to the shot, warning doctors to watch for possible rare, abnormal bleeding in the brain. But as the pandemic worsens in Europe, officials are desperate to fully resume its use.
articles.lead_paragraph: As another pandemic wave staggers Europe, the continent’s top drug regulator said on Thursday that the AstraZeneca vaccine was safe, hoping to allay fears of possible side effects from a shot that is a vital weapon in the anti-coronavirus arsenal, and prompt more than a dozen countries to resume using it.
articles.byline: By Marc Santora and Monika Pronczuk

articles.headline: Teen Vogue Editor Resigns After Fury Over Racist Tweets
articles.snippet: The hiring of Alexi McCammond, who was supposed to start at the Condé Nast publication next week, drew complaints because of racist and homophobic tweets she had posted a decade ago.
articles.abstract: The hiring of Alexi McCammond, who was supposed to start at the Condé Nast publication next week, drew complaints because of racist and homophobic tweets she had posted a decade ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: Alexi McCammond, who made her name as a politics reporter at the Washington news site Axios, had planned to start as the editor in chief of Teen Vogue next Wednesday. Now, after Teen Vogue staff members publicly condemned racist and homophobic tweets Ms. McCammond had posted a decade ago, she has resigned from the job.

articles.headline: How Racism and Sexism Intertwine to Torment Asian-American Women
articles.snippet: Many viewed the shooting rampage in Atlanta that left eight people dead as the culmination of a racialized misogyny that they say has long been directed at them.
articles.abstract: Many viewed the shooting rampage in Atlanta that left eight people dead as the culmination of a racialized misogyny that they say has long been directed at them.
articles.lead_paragraph: After eight people, six of them Asian women, were fatally shot this week in a rampage near Atlanta, a law enforcement official said that in the gunman’s own words, his actions were “not racially motivated,” but caused by “sexual addiction.”

articles.headline: Accused Gunman Had Visited Massage Parlors He Targeted, Police Say
articles.snippet: The suspect, who was a customer at two of the spas in the Atlanta area that were attacked this week, spent time in a rehab clinic for a self-described sexual addiction.
articles.abstract: The suspect, who was a customer at two of the spas in the Atlanta area that were attacked this week, spent time in a rehab clinic for a self-described sexual addiction.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — He checked himself into a rehab clinic for a self-described sexual addiction. He was so intent on avoiding pornography that he blocked websites from his computer and only used a flip phone. He worried to a roommate about falling “out of God’s grace.”
articles.byline: By Richard Fausset, Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs, Ruth Graham and Jack Healy

articles.headline: Fear and Hostility Simmer as Ethiopia’s Military Keeps Hold on Tigray
articles.snippet: Accounts of atrocities keep coming in as the wounded flee to the regional capital, Mekelle, where Tigrayans say they are being winnowed for their leaders’ rebellion.
articles.abstract: Accounts of atrocities keep coming in as the wounded flee to the regional capital, Mekelle, where Tigrayans say they are being winnowed for their leaders’ rebellion.

articles.headline: U.S. Rushes to Expand Covid Vaccine Eligibility in a ‘Race Against Time’
articles.snippet: As coronavirus cases nationwide have plateaued, at least 20 states have committed in recent days to widening the list of people who may get a vaccine.
articles.abstract: As coronavirus cases nationwide have plateaued, at least 20 states have committed in recent days to widening the list of people who may get a vaccine.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Officials in at least 20 states have committed in recent days to opening coronavirus vaccine appointments to all adults in March or April, part of a fast-moving expansion as states race to meet President Biden’s goal of universal eligibility by May 1.
articles.byline: By Julie Bosman and Mitch Smith

articles.headline: ‘The Market Seems Crazy’: Start-Ups Wrestle With Flood of Offers
articles.snippet: As a deal frenzy mounts, propelled by financial vehicles known as SPACs, start-ups have become the prey.
articles.abstract: As a deal frenzy mounts, propelled by financial vehicles known as SPACs, start-ups have become the prey.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Ryan Schaffer, chief financial officer of Expensify, a start-up that makes business expense reporting software, has been relentlessly hounded since last year.

articles.headline: For Political Cartoonists, the Irony Was That Facebook Didn’t Recognize Irony
articles.snippet: As Facebook has become more active at moderating political speech, it has had trouble dealing with satire.
articles.abstract: As Facebook has become more active at moderating political speech, it has had trouble dealing with satire.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Since 2013, Matt Bors has made a living as a left-leaning cartoonist on the internet. His site, The Nib, runs cartoons from him and other contributors that regularly skewer right-wing movements and conservatives with political commentary steeped in irony.

articles.headline: Myanmar Protesters Answer Military’s Bullets With an Economic Shutdown
articles.snippet: From hospitals, railways and dockyards to schools, shops and trading houses, the country is at a standstill. Strikers hope their actions will force the army to return power after its coup on Feb. 1.
articles.abstract: From hospitals, railways and dockyards to schools, shops and trading houses, the country is at a standstill. Strikers hope their actions will force the army to return power after its coup on Feb. 1.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bank tellers’ windows are gathering dust. Cargo at the port sits uncollected. And in grand government ministries in Naypyidaw, the capital of Myanmar, stacks of documents are curling in the humidity. There are few people to process all the paperwork.

articles.headline: Tense Talks With China Left U.S. ‘Cleareyed’ About Beijing’s Intentions, Officials Say
articles.snippet: The Biden administration’s strategy to curb Beijing faces a stiff challenge as China uses its economic, diplomatic and military might to deflect criticism.
articles.abstract: The Biden administration’s strategy to curb Beijing faces a stiff challenge as China uses its economic, diplomatic and military might to deflect criticism.
articles.lead_paragraph: ANCHORAGE — The Biden administration’s first face-to-face encounter with China ended Friday after a vivid demonstration of how the world’s two largest economic and technological powers are facing a widening gulf of distrust and disagreements on a range of issues that will shape the global landscape for years to come.
articles.byline: By Lara Jakes and Steven Lee Myers

articles.headline: How Close Are China and Germany? Consider ‘Little Swabia.’
articles.snippet: The city of Taicang illustrates the tight ties between the countries — and how difficult it could be for President Biden to win allies in his campaign to isolate Beijing.
articles.abstract: The city of Taicang illustrates the tight ties between the countries — and how difficult it could be for President Biden to win allies in his campaign to isolate Beijing.
articles.lead_paragraph: TAICANG, China — German and Chinese flags flutter along tree-lined avenues. Workers are erecting a shopping-and-hotel project with the half-timbered style of architecture more typically found in places like Bavaria or the Black Forest. A nearby restaurant serves Thuringia grilled sausages, fried pork sausages and lots of sauerkraut.
articles.byline: By Keith Bradsher and Jack Ewing
